page.heading: Introduction

item.text: Wiped out your lawn along with the weeds?
Made a second trip to the store?
Made a dash for fresh air after mixing two cleaning products?
Sprayed your tomatoes for bugs and killed your plants instead?

page.caption: Have you ever...Wiped out your lawn along with the weeds? (You figured that if some lawn treatment was good, more should be better.) Made a second trip to the store? (The product you bought the first time turned out to be wrong for the job.) Made a dash for fresh air after mixing two cleaning products? (You figured if one was good, two would be even better.) Sprayed your tomatoes for bugs and killed your plants instead? (The spray you used wasn't supposed to be used on vegetables.)

page.heading: Introduction

item.text: The task of reading a pesticide label is the foundation of good pest management.
You can avoid mishaps if you...

page.caption: Incredible as it may seem, the humble task of reading a pesticide label is really the foundation of good pest management. You can avoid mishaps like the ones just described by taking the time to...Read the label.

page.heading: Introduction

item.text:
(Click the Vikane label to see examples
of just how confusing labels can be.)

page.caption: A pesticide label may not always be the most user-friendly, at-a-glance reading material. Click on the Vikane label, to see examples of just how confusing labels can be.

page.heading: Introduction

item.text:
Not the first thing that comes to mind for a pleasant,
enjoyable read

Not the kind of reading material you would want to
curl up with on the couch

page.caption: Certainly not anyone's idea of pleasant, light reading. Or the kind of reading material you would want to curl up with on the couch.

page.heading: About Labels

item.text: Don't have to love them, just read them
Respect them for what they are:
A critical tool in pesticide management
A job well done VS. a major botch-up

page.caption: Although they can be confusing, the last word is this: give labels a chance. You don't have to love them to read them. Just respect them for what they are: A critical tool in pesticide management. The difference between a job well done and a major botch-up.

page.heading: About This Lesson

item.text: <i>(Hold your mouse over each one of these areas of the label to view the area in detail.)<i/>

page.caption: A pesticide label has 9 required areas. On the job, you'll be dealing with all 9 of these areas. In order to help you digest all the important material about the label, this lesson has been divided into two parts. In Part 1, you'll learn about the label in general, and about the first 6 required areas. Hold your mouse over each one of these areas in the graphic to view the area in detail.

page.heading: Objectives
page.subHeading: In This Lesson You Will Learn to:

item.text: Identify the role and importance of the label in preparing for a pesticide application.
Correctly identify the first 6 of the 9 required content areas of a pesticide label.

page.caption: In this lesson you will learn to: appreciate the critical value and importance of labels when preparing for a pesticide mission and correctly identify the first 6 of the 9 required content areas of a label, so that you can read a label with ease and confidence.

page.heading: Prepare! Prepare! Prepare!

item.text: Appears to be a daunting task
Key to any pesticide application: meticulous preparation

page.caption: Captain O'Brien is preparing for a pesticide application to control mosquitoes at Fort Fenomenal. Preparing to apply pesticides appears to be a daunting task. Meticulous preparation will make the task more manageable and is essential to ensure a safe and effective application.

page.heading: Prepare! Prepare! Prepare!

item.text: Need to have the right equipment
Calculate the proper amounts
Mix them up correctly
Know what pesticide is best to use for the job
You are liable for:
Environmental damage
Harm to people and pets
Property damage

page.caption: So many things can go wrong. It is difficult to apply pesticide. You have to get the right equipment, calculate the proper amounts, mix them up correctly, and know what pesticide is best to use for the job. There are so many different things to consider. Accidents can happen, and even if you are working for the government, you are liable for environmental damage, harm to people and pets, even stains on someone's car that ruin a paint job.(Click on the button titled "when things go wrong" for a real-life example of a pesticide disaster).

page.heading: Prepare! Prepare! Prepare!

item.text: Biologically active--can cause harm to living organisms
Potential for environmental damage

page.caption: Pesticides are very biologically active chemicals. That can cause harm to living organisms. There is always the potential to cause environmental damage, such as depicted in this photo.

page.heading: Prepare! Prepare! Prepare!

item.text: Biologically active--can cause harm to living organisms
Potential for environmental damage
Risks to human health
Harm to self
Harm to bystanders

page.caption: In addition to the risk of environmental damage, Captain O'Brien is also keenly aware that pesticides pose a risk to human health. Although the risk of harming human beings is small, if pesticides are used incorrectly, careless applicators might accidentally injure themselves or bystanders.

page.heading: Pesticides Not Fail-Safe

item.text: Choosing the wrong pesticide for the task
Misapplying the correct pesticide
Failing to achieve desired result

page.caption: Another issue the Captain considers is the potential for a failed application. Pesticides are NOT fail-safe chemicals. A careless applicator could choose the wrong pesticide for the task or, misapply the correct pesticide, and fail to achieve the desired effect.

page.heading: Under Use, Not a Legal Violation

item.text: Wastes time and materials
Needless harm to people and property from uncontrolled pests
Contributes to pesticide resistance

page.caption: The Captain knows that a failed application from under use of pesticide is not a legal violation, however, a failed application due to overuse is ALWAYS a legal violation. In any case, failed applications waste both time and materials, and may needlessly expose people or property to damage from pest activity. Failed applications also contribute to the development of pesticide resistance.

page.heading: About the Label
page.caption: Captain O'Brien knows that there is a vast amount of information and guidance available about pesticides and their usage. But the ESSENTIAL reference is the pesticide label itself.

page.heading: About the Label

item.text: EPA-approved label:
Required by law since 1972
Any application contrary to the label is Illegal

page.caption: Since 1972 the federal government has required that all pesticides sold within the United States bear an EPA-approved label. Thus, pesticide labels became legal documents. This means the label is the law! Furthermore, any pesticide application that is contrary to the directions found on the label is considered an illegal operation.

page.heading: About the Label

item.text: Considered the most expensive literature available
At least $30 million for research that leads to the wording on ONE label

page.caption: The information found on pesticide labels is considered the most expensive literature available. Pesticide manufacturers spend at least 30 million dollars conducting the research that ultimately leads to the wording on ONE label.

page.heading: About the Label

item.text: A single pesticide label represents the work of:
Chemists
Entomologists
Pathologists
Toxicologists
Weed scientists
Others in industry, universities, and government

page.caption: A single pesticide label represents the work of laboratory and field scientists, including chemists, entomologists, pathologists, toxicologists, weed scientists and others in industry, universities, and government. All these specialists devote years of research to determine how a pesticide may be used in a safe and effective manner.

page.heading: About the Label and the Pesticide Applicator
page.subHeading: Follow the Label Instructions to the "Tee"

item.text: Must not use pesticides in any way that violates the instructions on the label
Problems result from applications made CONTRARY to the directions on the label

page.caption: Pest controllers must not use pesticides in a way that violates the instruction on the label. The careful applicator bases his work on the pesticide label instructions. Most pesticide problems result from applications made CONTRARY to the directions on the label.

page.heading: About the Label
page.subHeading: The 3 Main Purposes of a Pesticide Label

item.text: 1. Protect the user and the general public
2. Provide necessary information
3. Minimize environmental hazards

page.caption: As Captain O'Brien reviews the pesticide label, she recalls that there are three main purposes to every pesticide label:1) To protect the pesticide user and general public from any hazard associated with the chemical.2) To provide the pesticide user with any information necessary for a successful application.3) To minimize environmental hazards resulting from use of the product.

page.heading: About the Label

item.text: By law:
on the container itself
securely attached to the container
on any wrapper on outside containers
Additional labels must be supplied upon request

page.caption: The Captain doesn't have to search for a pesticide label. By law, all pesticide manufacturers must provide the label on the immediate pesticide container or securely attached to that container and on any wrapper or outside containers. In addition, the manufacturer is required to supply additional labels to any purchaser upon request.

page.heading: About the Characters
page.caption: From time to time you will take a look at the pest application misadventures of Skeeter and Willie. These characters are wholly fictional and designed solely to illustrate teaching points.

page.heading: The ANTics of Skeeter and Willie
page.caption: While Capt. O'Brien prepares for her pesticide application, across town, at Fort Runamuck, ace pest controller, Skeeter is also planning a pesticide application. Skeeter is preparing to wipe out an infestation of fire ants on the parade field, because the Boy Scouts will be holding their annual jamboree on the field this weekend. Skeeter has already looked through the pesticides on his shelf, and has decided to spray with a liquid he bought from his friend Willie. Willie says he invented this liquid by experimentation in his garage. According to Willie, it's deadly to fire ants and completely safe to use. He plans to market the new pesticide at flea markets across the United States, using the trade name "Faar Ain'ts Be Dammed".

page.heading: The ANTics of Skeeter and Willie

item.text: Should Skeeter use the homebrewed insecticide?

answer.answerText: Use Faar Ain'ts Be Dammed. Willie is a clever guy and he probably knows more about killing fire ants than some pinhead at a chemical plant.
answer.feedbackText: Incorrect. “Faar Ain’ts Be Dammed is NOT a registered pesticide and Skeeter knows nothing about the chemical.

answer.answerText: Try to buy into Willie's invention. Faar Ain'ts Be Dammed sounds like a big seller and Skeeter might end up as a wealthy man.
answer.feedbackText: Incorrect. Selling unregistered pesticides is a violation of State and Federal law.

answer.answerText: Run, Skeeter, Run!! Don't risk the wrath of the EPA by using this unregistered product! The unknown material may be harmful to human health and/or the environment.
answer.feedbackText: Skeeter should immediately remove the material from Fort Runamok and use a properly labeled pesticide for fire ant control.

answer.answerText: Don't use Faar Ain'ts Be Dammed for such a big project yet, but try testing the material on small jobs around Fort Runamuck to see how it works.
answer.feedbackText: Incorrect. Testing of new pesticides requires special permits and EPA supervision.

page.heading: The Label Must Be Readable
page.caption: Let's talk about general guidelines for label construction. The wording of a pesticide label must not be crowded or obscured. The words must be large enough to be read by anyone with normal vision. To further ensure that label instructions are readable, the words of a label are printed on a clear, background that contrasts with the color used for the text. Pesticide labels contain a great deal of technical information derived from the combined input of all those experts, but the language used on the label is simple, aimed at the reading level of the ordinary person.

page.heading: The Required Areas
page.subHeading: The 9 Content Areas of a Label
page.caption:
The information provided on pesticide labels must include nine required content areas, six of which are covered in this lesson, the remainder in part 2. The label usually includes additional information as well.
The 9 content areas are only required when applicable. Before looking at an actual label, keep in mind that these required areas will apply to some types of pesticides and not others. Not every label will contain all nine content areas --only the content areas applicable to that type of pesticide. For example: Vikane, a very lethal pesticide used to kill dry wood termites, must have a Restrictions for Use statement. However, Agnique, an unclassified pesticide that is available to the general public, will not have a Restrictions for Use statements, as it doesn't need one.

page.heading: The Required Areas
page.caption: This table shows all nine content areas, and how they apply to the pesticide Agnique MMF. Captain O'Brien is going to review each of these areas to be certain she fully understands the proper use of this pesticide. Why don't you take a moment to explore the required areas of the label with her?

page.heading: The 9 Content Areas of a Label
page.caption: Today the Captain is preparing to control mosquito larvae, immature insects living in standing water. She begins to review the label for Agnique, a pesticide especially designed for controlling immature mosquitoes and midges. Captain O'Brien finds the product or brand name, Agnique, at the top of the label.

item.text: Find the product name identified on the label shown below.

answer.feedbackText: This is a label for the pesticide, Merit.
No. While Merit is an insecticide, this is simply a generic term for a pesticide category.
No. “Active ingredient” is not the product name.
Sorry. Imidacloprid is the active ingredient of Merit.

page.heading: The 9 Content Areas of a Label

item.text: Manufacturers often include additional information about the pesticide after the product name
Additional Information:
Type
Formulation
Percentage/pounds of active ingredient

page.caption: Sometimes the manufacturer provides additional information about the pesticides after the product name. Such additional information as the type, formulation, percentage or pounds of active ingredient may be provided. Look at the brand name on the label of the pesticide, Merit. Here, the manufacturer is providing the additional information that Merit is a granular formulation with a zero point five percent active ingredient.

item.text: What is the formulation of Merit?

answer.feedbackText: Incorrect. Flowables are usually identified by the abbreviation F.
No. Emulsifiable concentrates are usually identified by the abbreviation E or EC.
Water soluble packets are identified by the abbreviation WSP.
Sorry. Granular pesticides are usually identified by the abbreviation G.

page.heading: The ANTics of Skeeter and Willie
page.caption: Oddly enough, Skeeter has been reviewing the label for Agnique MMF as well. He's decided that Agnique is probably a Latin word meaning "AGONY", and MMF means "Many More Effects". He's considering using Agnique against the stable flies that are currently plaguing animals in the barn at Fort Runamuck. He thinks the flies deserve anything they might get in the way of pain.

page.heading: The ANTics of Skeeter and Willie

item.text:
Will this application of Agnique on stable flies succeed?
(Click on the label icon to reference the label document.)

answer.answerText: Why not? Mosquitoes are flies and Agnique kills mosquitoes.
answer.feedbackText: Incorrect. Agnique MMF is designed to kill larval mosquitoes, not adult stable flies in a barn. Using Agnique MMF to treat a barn would constitute an illegal application because the site is not listed on the label.

answer.answerText: I'm not sure. Isn't Agnique a larvacide used in water?
answer.feedbackText: You’re partially right, but this is not the BEST answer. Stable fly larvae don’t live in water, so Agnique MMF doesn't kill them. Besides, using Agnique MMF to treat a barn would constitute an illegal application because the site is not listed on the label.

answer.answerText: Not a chance. In fact, Agnique isn't labeled for application in stables at ALL!
answer.feedbackText: Best answer! Using Agnique MMF to treat a barn would constitute an illegal application because the site is not listed on the label.

page.heading: The 9 Content Areas of a Label
page.subHeading: Area 2: Name and Address of Producer

item.text: The name and address of the producer or registrant are required on all labels

page.caption: The second required content area that you need to look for on the pesticide label is the name and address of the producer, registrant, or person for whom the pesticide was made. Captain O'Brien looks at the Agnique label and sees that the name of the producer is: Henkel Corporation at 4900 Este Avenue, Cincinnati, Ohio, 45232-1419.

page.heading: The 9 Content Areas of a Label
page.subHeading: Area 2: Name and Address of Producer

item.text: If the Registrant is not the producer, the name and address must include qualifiers such as:
packed for
distributed by
sold by

page.caption: What if the registrant of the pesticide is NOT the producer? If the registrant is not the producer, the name and address must include qualifiers such as: packed for, distributed by, or sold by, to show that the name on the label is not that of the actual producer.

item.text:
Who is the producer of this material?
(Click on the label icon to open the PDF version
of the Merit label, and reference page 4.)

answer.feedbackText: No. Henkel Corp. produces Agnique MMF. Bayer is the producer of Merit insecticide.
Right! Bayer is the producer of Merit insecticide.
No. Syngenta Professional Products makes Demand Pestab. Bayer is the producer of Merit insecticide.
Incorrect. Dow AgroSciences is the producer of Vikane fumigant. Bayer is the producer of Merit insecticide.

page.heading: The 9 Content Areas of a Label

item.text: Label must bear net weight or measure of content
Product only (does not include wrappers or other materials)
Average weight of the contents, unless explicitly stated as a minimum quantity
Actual contents will vary SLIGHTLY due to imperfections in manufacturing techniques

page.caption: The third required content area of a label is the Net Contents of a pesticide container. Each pesticide label must bear a statement describing the net weight or measure of content. The weight or measure does not include wrappers or other materials. It is the product only, the average content, unless explicitly stated as a minimum quantity. (The actual content of each container will vary SLIGHTLY because of imperfections in manufacturing techniques.)

page.heading: The 9 Content Areas of a Label
page.caption: For example, Captain O'Brien is planning a fairly large mosquito larvaciding project and needs a large amount of pesticide for the job. The statement "Net Contents 2.5 Gallons" appears on each container of Agnique MMF she's assembled for the job. On another, much smaller project, for controlling mosquito larvae in waste tires, she might have used a small spray bottle of Agnique MMF with the statement "1.05 quarts or 1 liter" on the label.

page.heading: The ANTics of Skeeter and Willie
page.caption: It so happens that at this very minute, Skeeter is working overtime trying to understand the Net Contents statement on Demand Pestab, so he can record how much pesticide he used during his recent application.

page.heading: The ANTics of Skeeter and Willie
page.caption: Skeeter's been staring at the label for some time when Willie walks in. The Net Contents read 40 X 0.2 ounces (5.65 gram) tablets, and in Skeeter's opinion, that doesn't help much. Fortunately, Willie has a lot of experience working in his laboratory in the garage, and he realizes that "gram" is a unit of the metric system. After a brief and frustrating few minutes of explanation by Willie, the boys retire to their favorite after work hangout for some intensive tutoring.

page.heading: The ANTics of Skeeter and Willie
page.caption: After hearing Willie explain the use of metric units, Skeeter notes that 16-ounce measurement on his bottle and wonders aloud, "what in the 'hail' would we do if rootbeer were measured in metric units"! On that sobering note, the boys lapse into a massive silence, each one trying to imagine how to handle Skeeter's problem at work with Demand Pestab.

page.heading: The ANTics of Skeeter and Willie
page.caption: The problem is this: Skeeter and Willie can easily use Demand Pestab, because the instructions are based on a certain number of tablets per application. But they can't accurately record or report the application until they learn something about both the British and the Metric systems of measurement.

page.heading: The ANTics of Skeeter and Willie

item.text: Right now, for example, Skeeter knows he and Willie have applied 40 Demand Pestabs, and he's read that each Pestab weighs 0.2 ounces or 5.65 grams. How much Pestab has actually been applied? (40 Pestab used; 1 Pestab = 0.2oz or 5.6 grams).

answer.answerText: 0.2 ounces X 40 tablets = 8 ounces, or about the volume of soda in an old-fashioned soda can.
answer.feedbackText: Incorrect. Ounces can measure 2 different things: weight or volume. In this case the solid Pestab tablets are measured in weight, not volume.
No. That’s wrong, and I have no idea what you’re talking about! The solid Pestab tablets are measured in weight, not volume.

answer.answerText: There are 40 tablets per box, so the boys have applied ONE BOX!
answer.feedbackText: No. Saying ONE BOX doesn’t clear things up very much. In fact, there is no such measure in mathematics. In this case the solid Pestab tablets are measured in weight, not volume.

answer.answerText: 0.2 ounces X 40 tablets = 8 ounces, or ½ pound weight.
answer.feedbackText: Correct! You realized that ounces can mean 2 things; weight or volume. The solid Pestab tablets are measured in weight, not volume.

page.heading: The 9 Content Areas of a Label

item.text: All U.S. pesticides are registered by the Environmental Protection Agency, and must bear a registration number

These numbers are always preceded by the phrase
"EPA Reg. No. or EPA Registration No."

page.caption: The fourth area of a label is the registration number. All the pesticides used in the United States are registered by the Environmental Protection Agency, and the label must bear a registration number. Captain O'Brien looks for the registration number of Agnique and finds the number 2302-14. These numbers are always preceded by the phrase "EPA Reg. No." or "EPA Registration No."

page.heading: The 9 Content Areas of a Label

item.text: Each registration number is unique to a given pesticide
The same pesticide would receive two different registration numbers if manufactured by two different companies

page.caption: The registration number is similar to our social security number, in that each registration number is unique to a given pesticide. In fact, the same pesticide would receive two different registration numbers if manufactured by two different companies.

page.heading: The 9 Content Areas of a Label

item.text: The one ESSENTIAL piece of information we need to correctly identify pesticides
Used for:
Pesticide inventories
To track usage
To report spills and medical emergencies

page.caption: A pesticide would also have two different registration numbers, if manufactured by one company, but distributed by another. The registration number is the one ESSENTIAL piece of information we need to correctly identify pesticides, so it's used for pesticide inventories, reports of pesticide usage, and in worst cases, to report spills, medical emergencies and other incidents.

item.text: Find the registration number on the Demand Pestab label.

answer.feedbackText: Correct! The EPA registration number for Demand Pestab is 10182-387.
Incorrect. This is the 1-800 phone number to call in case of a chemical emergency. The EPA registration number for Demand Pestab is 10182-387.
No. This is the establishment number for Demand Pestab. The EPA registration number for Demand Pestab is 10182-387.
Incorrect. But for a good time call... The EPA registration number for Demand Pestab is 10182-387.

page.heading: The 9 Content Areas of a Label

item.text: Identifies the establishment where the pesticide was manufactured.
Preceded by the words, EPA EST or EPA Establishment Number.

page.caption: The second important number to be found on a pesticide label is in area 5, the ESTABLISHMENT number. This number identifies the actual establishment where the pesticide was manufactured. It is preceded by the phrase "EPA Establishment Number". Captain O'Brien looks at the label for Agnique MMF and finds the establishment number is 53263-SC-01.

page.heading: Pop Question
page.subHeading: Same Pesticide Produced by Two Different Factories

item.text: Suppose that the manufacturer of Bugzaway produces this pesticide in more than one factory. Do you think that the establishment number for the Bugzaway produced at Factory A would be the same or different than that of the Bugzaway produced at Factory B?

answer.feedbackText: No. Each factory would have its own establishment number.
Correct! Each factory would have its own establishment number.

page.heading: The 9 Content Areas of a Label

item.text: The EPA requires production data from each facility

Important if a problem is identified with
a product manufactured in a particular factory

The establishment number may appear
in any suitable location:
On the label
On the pesticide container itself

page.caption: The establishment number is important from a regulatory standpoint because EPA requires production data from EACH facility. The number can also be important if a problem is identified with a product manufactured in a particular factory. In such case, the company could recall all the Bugzaway pesticide with the same establishment number. The establishment number may appear in any suitable location...on the label...or on the pesticide container itself.

item.text: How many establishment numbers are shown on the Strike label?

answer.feedbackText: No. Count again. There are 5 establishment numbers.
No. Count again. There are 5 establishment numbers.
No. Count again. There are 5 establishment numbers.
Right! There are 5 establishment numbers.

page.heading: The 9 Content Areas of a Label

item.text: Required on the front panel
Lists active ingredients (A.I.) name and percentage by weight
Lists inert ingredients total percentage by weight
If inert ingredients are present, active and inert ingredients must add up to 100 percent

page.caption: The ingredients statement is required on the front panel. It must list: Active ingredients (A.I.) - name and percentage by weight, and inert ingredients - total percentage by weight. Captain O'Brien takes a moment to review the ingredients of AGNIQUE MMF. AGNIQUE MMF is 100% active ingredient, so there is no statement as to the percentage of inert ingredients. If inert ingredients are present, the active and inert ingredients must add up to 100%.

item.text: What is the percentage of inert ingredients?

answer.answerText: Inert ingredient % is not mentioned on the label.
answer.feedbackText: No.The percentage of inert ingredients is listed in the ingredient statement. Demand Pestab contains 90% inert ingredients.
No.The percentage of inert ingredients is listed in the ingredient statement. Demand Pestab contains 90% inert ingredients.
No.The percentage of inert ingredients is listed in the ingredient statement. Demand Pestab contains 90% inert ingredients.
Demand Pestab contains 90% inert ingredients.

page.heading: The 9 Content Areas of a Label

item.text: Percentage of inert ingredients is required
Identity of inert ingredients NOT required
Inert ingredients are a proprietary secret
Not required by law to divulge this information, unless the ingredients pose an environmental or health hazard

page.caption: As stated, the manufacturer is required to identify the percentage of inert ingredients in a pesticide. However, the manufacturer is NOT required to identify the inert chemicals. Manufacturers regard the makeup of the inert ingredients as a proprietary secret, and they are not required by law to divulge this information, unless they may pose a hazard to man or environment.

page.heading: Lesson Conclusion

item.text: Review the Pesticide Labeling I Key Points document
(accessible from the OPTIONS menu)
Review glossary terms

page.caption: This concludes the lesson. You should now take a moment to review the key points document. Key points documents are available from the OPTIONS menu. You may also wish to review glossary terms before proceeding with the knowledge check.

answer.answerText: Prescription Treatment brand Pro Control Plus

question.questionText: What is the formulation of this product?
What is the the name of the producer of this pesticide?
Is the registrant of this pesticide also the producer?

answer.answerText: Yes, since there is only one name in area 2.
No. The party registering the pesticide is “A Prescription Treatment.” The producer is Whitmire Micro-General Research Labs, Inc.
There is no registrant for this pesticide.

question.questionText: Do the net contents include the packaging and the container?

answer.answerText: No, it's the pesticide only, minus packaging and container.
No, it includes the pesticide and the container, but not the packaging.
No, it includes the pesticide and the packaging, but not the container.

question.questionText: The Sun Valley Nursing Home is 15,000 cu. ft. of unobstructed space. According to the label, one 6 oz. can of Pro-Control Plus treats up to 5,000 cu ft. of unobstructed space. How many cans of pesticide will you need to treat the whole nursing home?
What is the EPA registration number?
Your boss wants you to make an entry on the monthly inventory report. Which number will you use for purposes of keeping inventory, report of usage, spills, or other incidents?
The EPA needs to track the production of Pro-Control in Missouri. Which number will the EPA use to track this data?
Which one of the following is an active ingredient in Pro Control Plus?
The inert ingredients in Pro-Control Plus total what percentage of the pesticide?
Fellow pesticide applicator, Skeeter, complains that the Pro-Control Plus label fails to meet readability guidelines. Which statement below is NOT a true EPA guideline for readability?

answer.answerText: Written so only a trained pesticide applicator can understand it.
Words not crowded on the page.
Text is large enough to read easily.
Words are printed on a contrasting color background.

question.questionText: Willie says that you should use your own intuition and experience when applying pesticides, as the label is only a guide. Is he right?

answer.answerText: Yes, Willie is right about this one.
No, the label is the law!
Maybe, I think it depends on which state you are in.
Yes, the label is only a guide if you are a CERTIFIED pest controller.

question.questionText: The following statements claim to describe pesticide labels in general. Which statement is FALSE?

answer.answerText: A label must be EPA certified.
Pesticides must be applied in accordance with the label.
Labels are relatively cheap to produce.
Additional copies of a label can be obtained from the manufacturer upon request.

question.questionText: Why is it critically important to read labels carefully before preparing for a pesticide application mission?

answer.answerText: Your annual rating and pay is based on your ability to read labels.
The fire marshall requires that we apply pesticide in accordance with the label.
By reading labels we show that this is a professional career field with its own requirements.
Labels are a critical tool in avoiding mishaps.

question.questionText: What is the chief cause of pesticide problems?

answer.answerText: Disagreements between certified applicators and those they supervise.
Manufacturers who fail to provide additional labels when requested.
Labels written in print too small to be read.
Applications made contrary to the directions on the label.
